child.pub-comments: “The Mortlocks to the south are quite divergent, the upper Mortlocks (Nama and Losap) less so than the lower (southernmost)” (Bender 1971:446).

“The total number of speakers of Trukese is at least 26,000: 18,500 in the lagoon, 6,000 in the Mortlocks, 950 in the Hall Islands, and an undetermined but sizeable number from the Mortlocks who have moved to Ponape as homesteaders” (Bender 1971:446).

child.publications: Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
child.pub-comments: “Fieldwork by Trifonovitch suggests the evidence of a third dialect concentrated in Oleai Village typical of those tracing ancestry to Elato and Lamotrek [atolls] yet different from that of Woleai Atoll; Elato and Lamotrek should possibly therefore be grouped under Carolinian together with Satawal, rather than under Woleai (Ulithian)” (Bender 1971:445).

child.geography: spoken in Tanapag Village on Saipan island

child.publications: Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
child.geography: spoken in Chalan Kanoa village on Saipan island

child.publications: Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “And there remains a high degree of mutual intelligibility among all dialects concerned – both on Saipan and in the source islands, which are: Satawal, 350 speakers; Pulusuk, 300; Puluwat, 400; Pulap, 400; and Namonuito, 500. […] There appear to be two main dialects of Saipan Carolinian: one concentrated in Tanapag Village, the other in Chalan Kanoa, and that both appear to be 'almost indistinguishable' from Pulusuk-Puluwat” (Bender 1971:445).

child.publications: Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
child.geography: spoken on the atolls of the Woleai area: Eauripik, Woleai, Ifalik, Faraulep, Elato, and Lamotrek
child.pub-comments: Population: 1,360 “A great deal of homogeneity has been reported for this dialect, although there is some indication that [the atolls of] Lamotrek and Elato may be closer to Satawal linguistically” (Bender 1971:444).

child.publications: Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
child.geography: spoken on four atolls that lie south of Palau: Tobi, Pulo Anna, Merir, and Sonsorol

child.geography: spoken on the atolls of Ulithi Proper, Fais, Sorol, and Ngulu

child.pub-comments: “Garvin reports two major dialects for the main island of Ponape: that of the municipality of Kiti, and that of the other five. Eacth of the three outer islands of Ngatik, Mokil and Pingelap has its own dialect. […] Ponapean has a total of 15,300 speakers: 13,000 on the main island, 500 on Ngatik, 800 on Mokil, and 1,000 on Pingelap” (Bender 1971:448).
Node not named by author. “Thus the Trukic Subfamily and Ponapean may be viewed as two subgroups at one level, which together constitute a higher-level subgroup” (Bender 1971:439).

child.publications: Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
child.pub-comments: “As to how the remaining nuclear languages – Kusaiean, Marshallese, and Gilbertese – relate to this [Trukic-Ponapean] subgroup little can be said” (Bender 1971:439). “There are about 3,600 speakers of Kusaiean, all—except for a few expatriates—on the island of Kusaie with no dialectal variation reported” (Bender 1971:449).

child.publications: Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population: about 44,000. “As to how the remaining nuclear languages – Kusaiean, Marshallese, and Gilbertese – relate to this [Trukic-Ponapean] subgroup little can be said” (Bender 1971:439). “Like the Marshalls, the Gilberts are relatively homogeneous linguistically, but with some north-south differentiation. Although there is some evidence of considerable Polynesian borrowing, probably as the result of extensive contact with the Ellice language, there is little doubt that Gilbertese is nuclear Micronesian” (Bender 1971:456).

child.publications: Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “As to how the remaining nuclear languages – Kusaiean, Marshallese, and Gilbertese – relate to this [Trukic-Ponapean] subgroup little can be said” (Bender 1971:439). “There are 19,000 speakers of Marshallese, with two major dialects coinciding with the two chains of the archipelago, and some minor dialectal differentiation—Ujelang in the west and Mejit in the east being especially distinctive” (Bender 1971:450).

child.publications: Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
child.pub-comments: “Narau has a population of over 4,000, but this includes large numbers of Gilbertese, Ellice Islanders, Chinese, and Europeans. It is not known to what extent members of these groups speak Nauruan. The Nauruan segment of the population is estimated at about 3,000” (Bender 1971:438).

child.publications: Bender, Byron W. 1971. Micronesian Language, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 426-465. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
child.pub-comments: “Yapese is spoken by over 4,000 people on Yap, and by 50 inhabitants of Ngulu, who are bilingual in Ulithian. There is some dialect differentiation from village to village” (Bender 1971:435).

root.pub-comments: “Most of the languages in Micronesia constitute a distinct subgroup of the Austronesian family, although there are also several languages within the area that belong to outside subgroups. Greater homogeneity is to be found in the western part of the area, and greater diversity to the east, thus (according to the age-area hypothesis) locating the historical focal point to the eastern edge of the Carolines” (Bender 1971:457).
